abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Management
            Support Project for Burundi were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            institutional strengthening and capacity building projects,
            though assessed for their contributory value in a broader
            reform process, must still be constructed with maximum
            internal cohesion and coherence. The results framework must
            always contain target values for project development
            objective, or PDO and intermediate outcomes and the number
            of measurable indicators should not be attenuated. The
            separation of powers constitutionally means distinct
            governance structures pertain in this sector. If added to
            this the judicial systems are under severe strain and held
            in especially low regard by the population (as is the case
            in Burundi), it must be questionable if the range of issues
            can be satisfactorily addressed in a project encompassing
            diverse other sectors. The supervision of big infrastructure
            works tend to be time-consuming for Project Coordinating
            Unit, or PCU, affecting the quality of supervision for other
            activities covered under the project. As recommendation for
            the future, the procurement process for such high value
            civil works contract should be handled separately by
            infrastructures project.

display_title.display_title:
Burundi - Economic Management
            Support Project  : Burundi - Economic Management Support Project

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Economic Management Support
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Economic Management
            Support Project (EMSP) for Burundi is to increase the
            efficiency of Burundi's macroeconomic, financial, and
            administrative management by strengthening accountability
            and transparency through improved procedures and controls.
            When offers had been received in mid 2009, the tenders were
            well above the budgeted amount in the project. By mail ref.
            no. 540/3622/2009 dated August 26, 2009, the Minister of
            Finance, on behalf of the Government confirmed to the World
            Bank that the gap of financing from approximately US$3.3
            million will be dealt with in the national budget, 2010 and
            2011. However, the Development Credit Agreement (DCA) had
            not envisaged the option of co-financing of this activity
            and had to be amended. At the same time, the construction of
            the building triggered some of the environmental and social
            policies of the World Bank. Consequently, a consultant was
            recruited by the Government in order to help update the plan
            of environment and safeguard management plan (ESMP) and
            whose preliminary activities will have had to be carried out
            before beginning of all work related to the construction of
            the building. This process took several months and
            construction finally began in January 2010, with a schedule
            of 18 months. In addition, there was insufficient quantity
            of the required quality of cement supplies and bricks
            available in the local market. There was also higher than
            usual rain fall causing some delays in construction of the
            foundation. During the implementation mission in November
            2010, the World Bank was informed that construction was
            approximately nine months behind schedule due to extensive
            delays in getting materials to Bujumbura from Dar-es-Salaam
            port. The new completion date is estimated to be March 2012,
            thus resulting in the attach request by the Minister of
            Finance on behalf of the Government of Burundi to extend the
            closing date of the project for one year.

display_title.display_title:
Burundi - Economic Management
            Support Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Economic Management Support
            Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Management Support Project
            for Burundi deals with government institutional structures
            at the central level. It specifically is to: a) restore
            orthodoxy and discipline; b) introduce transparency in
            economic, financial and human resources management, and to
            improve national account and macroeconomic framework; and c)
            modernize management through training, reorganization and
            introduction of information based management concepts and
            systems, centered on computerized information management.
            Impacts will be felt in the planning, approval, and
            demolition and construction stages. In the planning stage
            adverse impacts may occur as a result of poor design
            resulting in high energy consumption. In addition, there may
            be poor waste drainage resulting in land and water
            pollution. Corrective measures may be too prohibitive. Lack
            of proper approval or supervision may result in selection of
            incompetent firms and violation of building codes. Finally,
            construction and demolition may create noise, land, water
            and air pollution, as well as create hazard to public safety.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Restructuring of Economic
            Management Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Economic Management
            Support Project (EMSP) is to increase the efficiency of
            Burundi's macroeconomic, financial, and administrative
            management by strengthening accountability and transparency
            through improved procedures and controls. The changes
            include: (i) new project activities; (ii) the revision of
            project components; and (iii) the structure and functions of
            the project coordination and monitoring mechanisms. The
            project will pursue past and ongoing efforts to improve
            collection of economic data, modernize public finance
            management systems and institutions, reform procurement
            practices, strengthen oversight institutions, improve the
            judicial system and privatize public enterprises, including
            restructuring and privatizing the export crop sector.

Burundi - Restructuring of Economic
            Management Support Project
